item.title: South Korea and Japan Reach Deal on Wartime ‘Comfort Women’
item.description: The deal, in which Japan made an apology and promised an $8.3 million payment, may help mend ties between the countries.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: The foreign minister of Japan, Fumio Kishida, left, and his counterpart from South Korea, Yun Byung-se, at a news conference on Monday.

item.title: China Detains 12 People Over Shenzhen Landslide, Police Say
item.description: A former district official whose office oversaw the dumpsite died after jumping from a building, the state media also quoted the police as saying.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Excavators during a rescue operation after a landslide buried buildings at an industrial park in Shenzhen, China.

item.title: Iraqi Forces Retake Center of Ramadi From ISIS
item.description: The militants fled the western city’s government headquarters, although pockets of resistance remained in the north and east.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: FALIH HASSAN and SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: A soldier in a heavily damaged building in the Huz neighborhood of Ramadi, Iraq, on Sunday.

item.title: Sinosphere: As China Hungers for Coal, ‘Behemoth’ Studies the Ravages at the Source
item.description: Zhao Liang’s film “Behemoth” depicts the harmful effects of mining on Inner Mongolia’s grasslands, and its people.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:description: In Zhao Liang’s film “Behemoth,” which uses on-screen text adapted from Dante’s “Divine Comedy,” a coal miner plays a role akin to that of Virgil, the guide, holding a mirror on his back as he leads viewers.

item.title: Family’s Tragedy Goes Beyond One Boy
item.description: The death of Alan Kurdi, 2, which focused the world on refugees, was just one chapter of a sprawling family’s story in its desperate attempts to escape Syria and find a new home.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hivrun Kurdi, an aunt of Alan's, with her children in a refugee shelter in Bramsche, Germany, this month. Weeks after Alan drowned, Hivrun and her children made the same perilous sea journey from Turkey to Greece.

item.title: Obama’s ‘Boots on the Ground’: U.S. Special Forces Are Sent to Tackle Global Threats
item.description: While President Obama has said he opposes sending Americans to fight in far-flung countries, his administration carves out exceptions for Special Operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An American Special Operations officer in Parwan in 2014. Such forces are taking on a larger combat role in Afghanistan.

item.title: Tied Vote on Catalan Separatist Leader in Spain
item.description: An election to let Artur Mas, who lost a crucial vote last month, serve another term as the head of a coalition of parties supporting Catalonia’s secession yielded a deadlock on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Argentina’s New President Moves Swiftly to Shake Up the Economy
item.description: Mauricio Macri’s economic changes are roiling Argentina, accentuating the divide he wanted to bridge and leading some Argentines to doubt whether he will be a change for the better.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: Argentina's new president, Mauricio Macri, whose devaluation of the peso has eroded salaries.

item.title: Last Refuge From Taliban for Afghans May Prove No Refuge at All
item.description: Lashkar Gah, the capital of Helmand Province where many Afghans have fled seeking safety, is under threat from insurgents.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and TAIMOOR SHAH
item.media:description: Members of the Afghan security forces searched travelers amid heightened security measures on local roads in Helmand Province on Sunday.

item.title: Women's War: Flawed Justice After a Mob Killed an Afghan Woman
item.description: At first, the trial and convictions in the death of Farkhunda Malikzada seemed a victory in the long struggle to give Afghan women their due in court. But a deeper look suggests otherwise.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Hundreds of people gathered in Kabul to bury Farkhunda. Women carried her coffin, breaking the custom of staying away from funerals.

item.title: Desperate Gaza Escape Try Leads to Death, and Recriminations
item.description: Ishaq Khalil Hassan, 28, hoped to wade into Egypt for medical care, his family says. Naked and unarmed, he was gunned down by border guards.
item.dc:creator: MAJD AL WAHEIDI and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ishaq Khalil Hassan's mother, Amna Hassan.

item.title: Vichy Journal: Vichy Yearns to Shed Heavy Yoke of Past Shame
item.description: Ghosts of the dark years linger in what was once the collaborationist capital, though historians note the government was to blame, not the city.
item.dc:creator: JESSICA BURSTEIN
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: "There are many stories about this city, and then there’s the truth," Vichy's mayor said.

item.title: British Army Is Deployed as Flooding Submerges Northern England
item.description: Swollen rivers and heavy rainfall brought misery to swathes of the north, and unleashed a spate of political recriminations.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: British soldiers and emergency workers evacuated residents in York, England, on Sunday after large swathes of the country's north were hit by flooding.

item.title: ISIS Puts Up Resistance to Slow Iraqi Troop Advance in Ramadi
item.description: Islamic State fighters are putting up a tough fight in the militant-held city of Ramadi, slowing down the advance of Iraqi forces, a senior Iraqi commander said Sunday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers on Sunday entered the Hoz neighborhood in central Ramadi, the capital of Anbar Province, where they are leading a concerted effort to drive out Islamic State fighters.

item.title: China Passes Antiterrorism Law That Critics Fear May Overreach
item.description: Opponents who had seen a draft version said it grants broad new powers that could be abused to monitor peaceful citizens and steal commercial secrets.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Goh Chai Hin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The police presence was increased in the Sanlitun neighborhood of Beijing over the weekend after several foreign embassies warned of heightened security risks there around Christmas.

item.title: India Offers Atypical Video Challenges
item.description: Both local entertainment companies, as well as Netflix, Amazon and 21st Century Fox, hope to persuade Indians to pay for online streaming, but changing current habits will be difficult.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL
item.media:credit: Asmita Parelkar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aparajita Jamwal, a yoga instructor, filming an instructional video.

item.title: China Says It Will Expel French Journalist
item.description: The reporter, Ursula Gauthier, had written an article criticizing Beijing’s attempt to link the Paris attacks to ethnic violence in China’s northwest.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Veteran International Prosecutor Foresees War Crimes Trials for ISIS
item.description: Stephen Rapp said it would be “unthinkable” to do without a process of justice in the future for any peace agreement to have the support of the Syrian people.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:description: Stephen J. Rapp, an American lawyer who has been involved in international prosecutions.

item.title: Drought Deepens South Africa’s Malaise
item.description: The full impact of the drought and resulting poor harvests will be felt only in the months ahead, but they have already left 29 million people without reliable access to food, the U.N. says.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: T. J. Koee, a cattle farmer for 16 years in Setlagole, South Africa, listed the drought’s toll this year: 19 dead cows, 38 left, none sold.

item.title: ISIS, Facing Losses, Releases Recording Said to Be of Leader
item.description: In a recorded speech, whose authenticity could not be confirmed, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi implored more Muslims to fight on behalf of his group.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: FALIH HASSAN and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi in 2014. The Islamic State issued a recording on Saturday of a speech purportedly made by Mr. Baghdadi.
